thread.title: Chinese search giant Baidu's video streaming unit iQiyi launches $2.4 billion US IPO

author: Qilai Shen
title: Chinese search giant Baidu's video streaming unit iQiyi launches $2.4 billion US IPO
text:
Gold Chinese search giant Baidu's video streaming unit iQiyi launches $2.4 billion US IPO Chinese video streaming service provider iQiyi, a unit of search engine giant Baidu , has launched an initial public offering in New York worth up to $2.4 billion. It plans to offer 125 million American depositary shares priced at $17 to $19 each, the company said in a filing to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Baidu owns 80.5 percent of the Netflix-like video platform IQiyi, which will list on the Nasdaq, said it expects to use about half of the proceeds to broaden and enhance its content offering while 10 percent would be earmarked to strengthen technology. The rest would go towards general corporate purposes. Published 15 Hours Ago Reuters Qilai Shen | Bloomberg | Getty Images A man walks past a sign for Baidu Inc. at the entrance to the Baidu Technology Park in Beijing, China, on Friday, Nov. 25, 2016. 
Chinese video streaming service provider iQiyi, a unit of search engine giant Baidu , has launched an initial public offering in New York worth up to $2.4 billion, seeking to expand its range of content. 
The listing is expected to give the firm extra financial muscle as it squares off against rivals in the Chinese market, including Alibaba's service Youku Tudou Inc. iQiyi has around 400 million users. 
It plans to offer 125 million American depositary shares priced at $17 to $19 each, the company said in a filing to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Underwriters have an option to sell an additional 18.75 million shares, which if exercised in full could bring the value of the deal to about $2.7 billion. 
iQiyi, which will list on the Nasdaq, said it expects to use about half of the proceeds to broaden and enhance its content offering while 10 percent would be earmarked to strengthen technology. The rest would go towards general corporate purposes. 
Baidu owns 80.5 percent of the Netflix-like video platform and will continue to be its controlling shareholder upon completion of the offering. 
IQiyi saw its 2017 revenue jump to 17.38 billion yuan ($2.7 billion), a gain of 55 percent over the previous year. It made a net loss of 3.74 billion yuan. 
Last year, Netflix agreed to provide some of its content, such as "Stranger Things," to iQiyi, giving the U.S. firm access to the Chinese market. 
In an interview with CNBC at the World Economic Forum in Davos , Baidu's President Ya-Qin Zhang, hinted at more deals to come with Netflix. 
Bilibili, another Chinese video streaming company, also set tentative pricing for its New York listing, seeking to raise as up to $525 million. 
Its depository shares will be offered in a range of $10.50 to $12.50 each. The deal includes an option for an additional 6.3 million shares to be sold. 
â€” CNBC's Arjun Kharpal contributed reporting. Related Securities
